answer_html: And so we see that the function is decreasing up to x = 0, where it has a global minimum and then is increasing.
answer_latex:
And so we see that the function is decreasing up to \emph{x} = 0, where
it has a global minimum and then is increasing.
hints_html: Local extrema occur potentially at critical points. Find them and then justify whether or not they are local extrema.
hints_latex:
Local extrema occur potentially at critical points. Find them and then
justify whether or not they are local extrema.
hints_raw: Local extrema occur potentially at critical points. Find them and then justify whether or not they are local extrema.
question: 4 (ii)
sols_html:
Taking the derivative gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 9x = x(x^{2} - 6x + 9) = x(x-3)^{2}.\end{aligned}\]

Which allows to write a sign table for the derivative.

[c]@llllll@ & & \(\displaystyle 0\) & & \(\displaystyle 3\) &
\(\displaystyle x\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle (x-3)^2\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) & \(\displaystyle -\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\) & \(\displaystyle 0\) & \(\displaystyle +\)
 \(\displaystyle f(x)\) & \(\displaystyle \searrow\) & & \(\displaystyle \nearrow\) & & \(\displaystyle \nearrow\)

And so we see that the function is decreasing up to x = 0, where it has a global minimum and then is increasing.
sols_latex:
Taking the derivative gives

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f'(x) = x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 9x = x(x^{2} - 6x + 9) = x(x-3)^{2}.
\end{align*}

Which allows to write a sign table for the derivative.

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllll@{}}
& & $\displaystyle 0$ & & $\displaystyle 3$ &\\
$\displaystyle x$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle (x-3)^2$ & $\displaystyle +$ & & $\displaystyle +$ &
$\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle f'(x)$ & $\displaystyle -$ & $\displaystyle 0$ &
$\displaystyle +$ & $\displaystyle 0$ & $\displaystyle +$\\
~$\displaystyle f(x)$ & $\displaystyle \searrow$ & &
$\displaystyle \nearrow$ & & $\displaystyle \nearrow$\\\\
\end{longtable}

And so we see that the function is decreasing up to \emph{x} = 0, where
it has a global minimum and then is increasing.

:<math> \displaystyle
f'(x) = x^{3} - 6x^{2} + 9x = x(x^{2} - 6x + 9) = x(x-3)^{2}.
</math>

Which allows to write a sign table for the derivative.

| style="border-bottom: solid 1px;" |
| style="border-bottom: solid 1px;" | <math>\displaystyle +</math>
| style="border-bottom: solid 1px;" | <math>\displaystyle 0</math>

|-
|}

And so we see that the function is decreasing up to ''x'' = 0, where it has a global minimum and then is increasing.
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.\end{aligned}\]

ii) Find the x-values of all the local maxima and minima of f(x).

Note: if maxima or minima do not exist, say so.
statement_raw:
Consider the function
:<math>
f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x^{4} - 2x^{3} + \frac{9}{2}x^{2}.
</math>

ii) Find the x-values of all the local maxima and minima of f(x).

''Note: if maxima or minima do not exist, say so.''
